topic.title: Neighbor put a security camera directly overwatching my backyard
topic.body:
Who's in the wrong here? Don't get me wrong, I'm not involved in anything shady, but you know... If somebody breaks in and I have to kill him I'd rather throw his body somewhere than have to face """justice""" and probably go to jail for 20 years because I didn't wait for him to get inside my house or he only had a knife or whatever bullshit. Same for hiding stuff by burying it in my backyard, I'd rather have the option to do that...
Maybe should use a pellet gun to take that fucker out when the power goes down?

topic.title: The final redpill about software
topic.body: Computer software should be kept as static as possible, both upstream and on your own computer. Changing things should only be the last resort, for instance to patch security holes, or if the old hardware becomes unattainable. Otherwise you should spend as much time as possible to familiarize yourself with the software and patch/work around bugs as needed to keep the system in working order.

1577612746_16dnrZKRMLhQCjv6nxx7tP5KJ2H2P.body:
> [anshorei](#comment_71_1CgdRv2BFaVqNfmK3qGVYDuA7EDmk8dJVS): localhost [...]

You can but only a single site on localhost, unless they don't use networking and are 100% local, in which case they don't count as sites. So, if you set up ZeroNet you can only access, say, ZeroTalk but not any other site on ZeroNet. And for example you can't access ZeroTalk on one port and Freenet on the other.

> [maho911](#comment_22_168Ze2ScKyzmQMpGqpwA3VkznNDke9z9s3): After thinking about this for a while, it seems the best choice (after http://127.0.0.1:43110 and webproxy gateways) is actually some giant forum system [...]

> [xane](#comment_16_1btdnzDG8dG58aW9vnKWmCHV59dNTJfn7): If you're going to put random arbitrary restrictions on people's answers, you should have said so in the OP.

Newsflash, everyone. Youtube and Wikipedia are the same site now because I installed a proxy on my machine that allows me to access both on http://127.0.0.1

> [xane](#comment_17_1btdnzDG8dG58aW9vnKWmCHV59dNTJfn7): I'm talking about zeronet and the zites on it, idiot. Proxies aren't sites.

Wow, cool it down with the insults, bro.
I'm talking about ZeroNet sites too. You can choose a ZeroNet site but only one. It doesn't matter that all of them are on the same domain (localhost). Got it?

1569767202_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
>I'm going to unfollow this thread, because I know a shitstorm will follow.
Why do you care to send a message to anonymous people on the Internet if you won't even read the response?
If you think our opinions on the whole aren't even worth reading then go post yours somewhere else, bro.
>This is where I think natural selection is better than harming possibly all of today's generation of infants and children. Harming a whole group of the population to save a few lives is nonsensical to me.
It's a complex issue. We've been exposed to mosquitoes for thousands of years and still get pathogens, which suggests the rate of adaptiation with respect to that threat has slowed down or reached a plateau.  On the other hand, we've never been exposed to pyrethrins, so we might evolve to it fast and become immune to its effects (but unfortunately so might mosquitoes).
From an utilitarian point of view, it might be worth it to cause some small harm to everyone to prevent a big harm to a few. It depends on the number and how bad you consider the harms.
Overall I think it probably shouldn't be done.

1577617777_1DfS5W4f4uaamYXGawCNnG4niUe4u.body:
> [anonymouslogin](#comment_176_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): Education should start early, over 50% of the children born in the US are unplanned...but I digress. This thread is all about crypto! Yay P2P transactions. Use a fungible cryptocurrency and smile as you pass by the centralized banks.

Yes, I agree. Children should be sent to school early on. Their parent's beliefs shouldn't be the main influence on their development and ideology.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_178_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): Not only are there more than two sexes, there have been various genders in any number of cultures through the entire written history of humanity and likely before. Often these multi-faceted people were elevated in social positions, sometimes perceived as gods.Evolution and mutation, or experimentation as you call it does produce culls, it also refines the surviving population and bolsters the reproductive and survival fitness of the organism. I agree that intelligence is not the defining factor for an evolutionary vector, fitness however is. Ants are incredibly diverse and versatile, literally products of evolutionary forces acting in a short time frame, but if you really want to be impressed take a look at the world of bacteria. Exponential growth rates, and natural selection happening before your eyes. Put a culture in an antibiotic, inside of a few hours depending on temperature, you will have a population resistant to the antibiotic. Homo sapiens sapiens is traveling the same curve over a much longer time frame. To the topic, financial markets are no different, and regulation by governments is not going to be effective at stemming the free communication between individuals the internet has brought us, ushering in a new era of bartering, and the storage and transfer of value at the individual level that cashless transactions will bring through this network. If you have ever tried to resist a government, then you know the first thing they do is go after your bank account. The centralized banks are the pawns in this fight for governance, and they are handsomely compensated for their services by the ruling elite. My humble opinions...

> [fke13](#comment_103_1DZBbYJmuFQvVTe2X2Enrveziw3vN1JQXz): You may try to use paint bullets. The rest of Your argumentation is nonsense, but a paint ball bullet WITHOUT HURTING OR BREAKING ANYTHING is quite a nice response, provided that You do not "get caught on camera" doing it. So choose Your angle and do not walk with the paint bullet gun in front of the camera. Or better yet, use a self-made sling-shot to throw some ordinary children's paint at it. Another option is to use an ordinary laser pointer and place it firmly pointing directly to the camera. Test the pointer with Your cellphone camera first. The laser option is best, because it does not leave any traces for the Police to accuse You of and You may say that You were just working on a light show and all Your neighbor's talk is "without any sound argumentation about Your wrongdoings".

The light show argument won't fly with the police when the beam was obviously aimed towards the camera and nobody saw or heard people partying at my place, it's much easier to see a laser than a pellet gun projectile, and I wouldn't know how much damage I inflicted, if any.
A paintball might work until they clean it up or finally get the message and take out/move the camera, but they're much less accurate than pellet guns so I'd have to get many more shots if I even manage to hit it at all, raising the chances of a neighbor seeing me, and they're much less common than pellet guns, raising the incrimination factor if they did raid my house and found it in my possession.

>Besides, may be the camera is not even meant to film Your yard, it just accidentally films Your yard and they actually care only about their yard.
Sure. It's not them I'm concerned about. It's me getting in trouble with the cops and they requesting the footage from the neighbors to see stuff they might need to convict me. And also just the picture being sent to The Cloud and being seen by God knows who.
>You also have an option to place 2 cameras looking at their yard and at some point they might want to remove their camera as an exchange move.
The problem is the property in the back is a farm, so they wouldn't give a shit if I put cameras overwatching them. As this is a residential area I think they're not supposed to raise animals here, but I don't want to snitch on them and bring attention to myself.
>Have You discussed an option that they just self place a blinder in front of the camera so that only their own yard is visible? May be they'll even show You the image of the camera so that You can verify that at least temporarily the blinder works?
I doubt that would work. And it would incriminate me if I later decide to disable the cameras.

But yeah, I guess putting a nylon cover over the wall would be the only real option, even though I'd lose the only decent view I had.

And subscribable whitelists could be implemented in ZeroNet too, there's no inherent advantage to site owners doing the moderating as opposed to your favorite self chosen volunteer list provider.

>[barnstokkr](#comment_38_19N49krDPpRvUbPMuHmxJVAXgKXPLQP32w): [citation needed]
I wasn't able to find a citation that specifically states what I stated, but you should be able to make the deductive step yourself by reading these referenced quotes:

>A computer program is a collection of instructions that performs a specific task when executed by a computer. Most computer devices require programs to function properly.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_program

>In cryptography, encryption is the process of encoding a message or information in such a way that only authorized parties can access it and those who are not authorized cannot.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encryption

From these we know that the computer must be able to access the information (the computer code for the site) for the code (sequence of instructions) to be able to instruct the computer what tasks to perform.

It's fairly hard to make a computer able to access some piece of information, but not the owner who is in physical possession of such computer. The reason is that encryption is generally achieved using a "key":

>In cryptography, a key is a piece of information (a parameter) that determines the functional output of a cryptographic algorithm. For encryption algorithms, a key specifies the transformation of plaintext into ciphertext, and vice versa for decryption algorithms. Keys also specify transformations in other cryptographic algorithms, such as digital signature schemes and message authentication codes.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_(cryptography)

This key must be stored inside the computer for it to be able to access the encrypted information. If the key is stored inside the computer, then it can be retrieved by the owner of the computer through various means, such as analyzing the data on the computer's hard drive using a "hex editor":

>A hex editor (or binary file editor or byte editor) is a computer program that allows for manipulation of the fundamental binary data that constitutes a computer file.
>With a hex editor, a user can see or edit the raw and exact contents of a file, as opposed to the interpretation of the same content that other, higher level application software may associate with the file format. For example, this could be raw image data, in contrast to the way image editing software would interpret and show the same file.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hex_editor

Therefore, long things short, it would be very hard for a site owner to encrypt his site and let the computer access it without the user being able to access it and manipulate it in various ways (including copying it).

>what are you even talking about.
I'm talking about multiple things.

>Encrypted site content.
Yes, that's one of the things I'm talking about.

>If the zite was encrypted you would not be able to view it in the first place, not even talking about copying it.
Correct.

>All code is client side on Zeronet.
Correct.

>You can clone anything.
Correct.

>Even this zite.
Correct.

>The only thing encrypted is the ZeroID signed posts.
Incorrect. ZeroID signed posts aren't necessarily encrypted, they are authenticated. On the other hand, there are certain things that are almost always encrypted, such as your ZeroMail e-mail.

>The moment you encrypt a zite, no one will be able to view it.
Correct.

>If you can view it, you can clone it.
Correct.

>Wow the astroturf is laid on thick here.
I'm not aware of such matters.

>Cope and seethe, you can't censor.
(And that's a good thing)

> [styromaniac](#comment_1629_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I guess that settles the discussion? We have our differences. If you want any kind of content allowed, then use a site that allows such a thing. Some of us administrators and users do not want the legal trouble.

Ok.

> [ranshit](#comment_10_17XPGJDqy3F7zfV3sa4aMJF2Mhpati6N12): I have to disagree, if I develop a platform, it is my choice to release the code obfuscated (which distracts from alterations) or developed with multiple comments in the hopes of assisting alterations.
You have the choice to do it, but the choice is morally wrong, because you are denying your users the four software freedoms.

>I do hope you realise that there are aspects of zeronet that are just as obfuscated such as the spam filter used by some board owners & ZeroID
That's still problematic, but a different issue, as the code for that functionality isn't running on the user's machine.

> [filips](#comment_406_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): You have the rights to decide if you want to make it possible for others to (easily) view your code.

If you distribute your software without also distributing the source code, then you are doing them a disservice. The users should have the right to understand and modify the software, and by not providing the source code you are denying them those rights.

> [styromaniac](#comment_1631_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): My last word on this is that Google serves CP as a result of being a search engine for porn. It's a heavy risk without a top notch lawyer.

Only if you're dumb enough to not use Tor and put your real name next to your username. And even then Tor developers and even nofish seem to do well enough even though their software is used to share CP. And that's why we need ZN sites to stop being sites and just become another piece of software. So the legal system can't pressure developers to censor anything.

1578036046_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
> [draugrdeathlord](#comment_271_12BRJSQrTETJVZzt2jHdqPywv3SdugSywC): Dont just rely on TOR, if the authorities want your head bad enough they already have exposed identities through TOR
What if the authorities don't want your head bad enough?  Then they haven't already exposed identities through Tor?
The fact is that, to this day, nobody has publicly been shown to have been arrested because of the government breaking Tor's anonymity, which isn't true for VPNs. I'm sure YOUR snowflake VPN hasn't sent people to jail yet, sure, but it also has been operating for a lot less years than Tor and serving a lot less users, so your sample size just isn't good enough for you to say it's better than using Tor.
What do pedos wanting to share their kiddie porn on the Internet use? What do druggies and the narcs wanting to help them get their fix use? VPNs? No, they use Tor.
>and there are compromised TOR relays for metadata analysis.
If you mean packet timings and outgoing data to the clearnet, sure, which hasn't lead to anyone being publicly de-anonymized.
